sentence.text: The second patient was ascertained at 27 weeks gestation after an ultrasound scan showed findings consistent with a severe, micromelic skeletal dysplasia.
The mother was a 21-year-old G2P1, and there was no reported family history of skeletal dysplasia.
A previously done first trimester ultrasound had been consistent with the mother's last menstrual period dates.
At 27 weeks, the long bones all measured at least 7 weeks behind what was expected for the gestational age.

A fetal magnetic resonance imaging scan (MRI) performed a few days later noted micromelic shortening of the upper and lower extremities, ulnar deviation of the wrists, and broad hands with short and broad fingers.
Only one long bone was visualized in the lower segment of both legs, and bilateral talipes was seen.
The chest size was noted to be slightly smaller than the abdomen, and the lung volumes were slightly lower than expected for gestational age.
There was poor visualization of the airway.
An abnormal cardiac axis was noted, but a fetal echocardiogram at 28 weeks showed no structural cardiac defects.
Kyphosis of the spine was noted at 33 weeks.
The diagnosis of AO was suggested based on the ultrasound and MRI findings, and the mother was counseled about the expected poor prognosis given these findings.
The mother chose to continue the pregnancy with a palliative care birth plan.
At 34 weeks of gestation, labor was induced because of persistent contractions and worsening polyhydramnios.
The baby had Apgar scores of 1 and 1, at 5 and 10 min, respectively, a weight of 1,984 g (25–50th centile) and a length of 38.1 cm (<3rd centile; 50th centile for 28 weeks of gestation).

The baby was noted to have a flat facial profile with significant mid-face hypoplasia, a short and upturned nose, a U-shaped cleft palate, a small chest, abnormal posturing of the hands, brachydactyly, and bilateral club feet (Fig. 4A).
She had an initial heart rate of less than 100 and had one gasping breath after delivery.
The family pursued comfort care, and their daughter died shortly after delivery.
A post-mortem skeletal survey showed severe shortening of the humeri, and the right humerus was almost bifid distally (Fig. 4B).
The ulnae were absent, and there was mild bowing of the radii, with deviation of the wrist to the ulnar side.
There was very little ossification of the carpals and metacarpals of both hands (Fig. 5).
The sacrum was not well ossified.
The femurs were shortened, and the tibiae were short and mildly bowed, with absent fibulae.
The feet had severe equinovarus deformity, with absent ossification of the hindfoot and forefoot bones, although there was ossification of five metatarsals and four distal phalanges bilaterally.
The right first metatarsal had a delta phalanx shape, and there was a slightly widened distance between the first and second metatarsals bilaterally.
The baby had reduced ossification of the cervical and thoracic vertebral bodies, and also had coronal clefts in the lower thoracic and lumbar vertebrae.

Mutation testing performed at Connective Tissue Gene Tests laboratory on a cord blood sample collected at the time of delivery showed c.541G > C, a transversion predicting p.Gly181Arg in exon 2 of the FLNB gene.
